ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Unlike the other two tracks of the Directed Studies program, the Philosophy track allows you to gain an introductory understanding of the integral meaty details of philosophical arguments (i.e. premise, argument, conclusion), in addition to helping you unravel the arguments outlined in Antique writings of authors such as Plato and Epicurus. By the end of the course, you will have an adept understanding of Philosophy and its roots, as well as some skill in outlying your own philosophically sound arguments.

Through this class, I learned an incredible breadth of philosophy by studying the writings of philosophers (pre and post-Christianity) that I would not have otherwise read. Reading and deconstructing philosophical writing from Plato and Aristotle to the Stoics and Skeptics, encouraged me to think critically and notice moves in argumentative writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish we got to spend more time on philosophers other than Plato and Aristotle.

Because we discussed, explored, and read about so many different schools of philosophy, the pacing of the class was incredibly fast. Instead of being able to explore any single writing in-depth, we were only able to cover the fundamentals and get exposure to the writing. Either way, I was impressed with the level of specificity and depth that we were able to reach in the seminar although it did require lots of time spent outside of class to read, annotate, and understand the writing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! If you are interested in DS, then you will definitely enjoy the Philosophy track.

I would recommend this course to another student if they were interested in philosophy or generally the humanities, but wanted to sample various schools of thought to discover what they might be most interested in. If you already know what you are passionate about, then it would be more rewarding to take a class that is geared towards that subject you can study thoroughly. However, this was a fun class, and rewarding to walk away with a general understanding of the philosophy schools and how they interact and understand the world.
